v="sqrt(4*g*h/3)"
problem.p: A small block of mass \(m\) slides on a long horizontal table when it encounters a wedge of mass 2\(m\) and height \(h\) (see the diagram). The wedge can also slide along the table. The block slides up the wedge all the way to the top and then slides back down, never getting over the top. What is the speed of the wedge at the moment the block leaves it? All surfaces are frictionless. The initial speed of the block is not given.
What physical principles/laws/ideas are best to use to solve this problem?
